pages.title: Yousef Saad
pages.text:
'''Yousef Saad''' is an I.T. Distinguished Professor of Computer Science in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering at the [[University of Minnesota]].<ref name="saad">[http://www-users.cs.umn.edu/~saad/ Yousef Saad] at the [[University of Minnesota]]</ref> He holds the William Norris Chair for Large-Scale Computing since January 2006. He is known for his contributions to the [[matrix computation]]s, including the iterative methods for solving large sparse linear algebraic systems, [[Eigenvalue, eigenvector and eigenspace|eigenvalue problems]], and [[parallel computing]]. Saad is listed as an [[ISI highly cited researcher]] in mathematics<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hcr3.isiknowledge.com/author.cgi?&link1=Browse&link2=Results&id=3453|title=Saad, Yousef, ISI Highly Cited Researchers|last=Thomson ISI|accessdate=12 January 2010}}</ref> and is the author of the highly cited book ''Iterative Methods for Sparse Linear Systems''. Yousef Saad is a SIAM fellow (class of 2010) and a fellow of the AAAS (2011).

==Education and career==
Saad received his B.S. degree in mathematics from the [[University of Algiers]], [[Algeria]] in 1970. He then joined [[Joseph Fourier University|University of Grenoble]] for the doctoral program and obtained a junior doctorate, 'Doctorat de troisieme cycle' in 1974 and a [[higher doctorate]], 'Doctorat d’Etat' in 1983. During the course of his academic career he has held various positions, including Research Scientist in the Computer Science Department at [[Yale University]] (1981–1983), Associate Professor in the University of Tizi-Ouzou in Algeria (1983–1984), Research Scientist in the Computer Science Department at Yale University (1984–1986), and Associate Professor in the Mathematics Department at [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] (1986–1988). He also worked as a Senior Scientist in the [[Research Institute for Advanced Computer Science]] (RIACS) during 1980–1990.<ref name="saad" />

Saad joined [[University of Minnesota]] as a Professor in the Department of Computer Science in 1990. At Minnesota, he held the position of Head of the Department of Computer Science and Engineering between January 1997 and June 2000. Currently, he is the I. T. Distinguished Professor of Computer Science at University of Minnesota.

==Books==
Saad is the author of a couple of influential books in [[linear algebra]] and [[matrix computation]] which include
*''Numerical Methods for Large Eigenvalue Problems'', Halstead Press, 1992.
*''Iterative Methods for Sparse Linear Systems'', 2nd ed., [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics]], Philadelphia, 2003.
*"Parallel Algorithms for Irregularly Structured Problems": Third International Workshop., [[Lecture Notes in Computer Science 1117]], IRREGULAR '96 Santa Barbara, CA, USA, August 19–21, 1996 Proceedings [1 ed.]
*"High-Performance Scientific Computing: Algorithms and Applications [1 ed.]"., [[Springer-Verlag London]]

He has also co-edited the following conference proceedings:

*A. Ferreira, J. Rolim, Y. Saad, and T. Yang, ''Parallel Algorithms for Irregularly Structured Problems'', Proceedings of Third International Workshop, IRREGULAR’96 Santa Barbara, CA USA, 1996. Lecture Notes in Computer Science, No 1117. Springer Verlag, 1996.
*D. E. Keyes, Y. Saad, and D. G. Truhlar, ''Domain-Based Parallelism and Problem Decomposition Methods in Computational Science and Engineering''. SIAM, Philadelphia, 1995.
*D. L. Boley, D. G. Truhlar, Y. Saad, R. E. Wyatt, and L. E. Collins, ''Practical Iterative Methods for Large Scale Computations''. North Holland, Amsterdam, 1989.

'''Daniel Shanks''' (January 17, 1917 – September 6, 1996) was an [[Americans|American]] [[mathematician]] who worked primarily in [[numerical analysis]] and [[number theory]]. He is best known as the first [[numerical approximations of π|to compute π]] to 100,000 decimal places, and for his book ''Solved and Unsolved Problems in Number Theory''.

==Life and education==

Dan Shanks (he insisted that everyone call him Dan<ref name="Williams NAMS obit">
{{cite journal
 | last = Williams
 | first = H. C.
 |date=August 1997
 | title = Daniel Shanks (1917–1996)
 | journal = Notices of the American Mathematical Society
 | volume = 44
 | issue = 7
 | pages = 813–816
 | publisher = American Mathematical Society
 | location = Providence, RI
 | issn = 0002-9920
 | url = http://www.ams.org/notices/199707/comm-shanks.pdf
 | format = PDF
 | accessdate = 2008-06-27
 }}
</ref>{{Rp|813}}) was born on January 17, 1917, in [[Chicago, Illinois]], and he is not related to the English mathematician [[William Shanks]], who was also known for computation of π. He earned his [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in physics from the [[University of Chicago]] in 1937 and a [[Ph.D.]] in Mathematics from the [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] in 1954. In between these two, Shanks worked at the [[Aberdeen Proving Ground]] and the [[Naval Ordnance Laboratory]], first as a physicist and then as a mathematician. During this period he also wrote his Ph.D. thesis (completed in 1949), despite having never taken any graduate math courses.<ref name="Williams NAMS obit" />{{Rp|813}}

After earning his Ph.D. in mathematics, Shanks continued working at the [[Naval Ordnance Laboratory]] and the Naval Ship Research and Development Center at the [[David Taylor Model Basin]], where he stayed until 1976. He then spent a year at [[National Bureau of Standards]] before moving to the [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] as an adjunct professor. He remained in Maryland for the rest of his life.<ref name="Williams NAMS obit" />{{Rp|813}}

Dan Shanks died on September 6, 1996.<ref name="Williams NAMS obit" />{{Rp|813}}

==Works==
Shanks worked primarily in [[numerical analysis]] and [[number theory]], but he had many interests and also did some work in [[black body]] radiation, [[ballistics]], [[mathematical identities]], and [[Epstein zeta function]]s.<ref name="Williams NAMS obit" />{{Rp|814}}

===Numerical analysis===
Shanks's most prominent work in numerical analysis was a collaboration with [[John Wrench]] and others to [[numerical approximations of π|compute the number π]] to 100,000 decimals on a computer.
<ref name="Shanks & Wrench">
{{cite journal
 | quotes = 
 | last = Shanks
 | first = Daniel
 |author2=[[John W. Wrench, Jr.]]
 | year = 1962
 | title = Calculation of π to 100,000 Decimals
 | journal = Mathematics of Computation
 | volume = 16
 | pages = 76–99
 | issn = 0025-5718
 | doi = 10.2307/2003813
 | issue = 77
 | jstor = 2003813
 | publisher = Mathematics of Computation, Vol. 16, No. 77
 }}
</ref>
This was done in 1961 on an [[IBM 7090]] and it was a major advance over previous work.<ref name="Williams NAMS obit" />{{Rp|814}}

Shanks was an editor of the ''[[Mathematics of Computation]]'' from 1959 until his death. He was noted for his very thorough reviews of papers, and for being a jack-of-all-trades who did whatever was necessary to get the journal out.<ref name="Williams NAMS obit" />{{Rp|813}}

===Number theory===
In number theory, Shanks is best known for his book ''Solved and Unsolved Problems in Number Theory''.<ref  name="SUPINT">
{{cite book | last = Shanks | first = Daniel | title = Solved and Unsolved Problems in Number Theory |edition = 5th| publisher = AMS Chelsea | location = New York | year = 2002 | isbn = 978-0-8218-2824-3 }}
</ref>
Hugh Williams described it as "a charming, unconventional, provocative, and fascinating book on elementary number theory."<ref name="Williams NAMS obit" />{{Rp|814}} It is a wide-ranging book, but most of the topics depend on [[quadratic residues]] and [[Pell's equation]]. The third edition contains a long essay on "judging conjectures".<ref name="SUPINT" />{{Rp|239 ff}} Shanks contended that there should be a lot of evidence that something is true before we classify it as a conjecture (otherwise it should be an Open Question and we should not take sides on it), and his essay gives many examples of bad thinking deriving from premature conjecturing. Writing about the possible non-existence of odd [[perfect numbers]], which had been checked to 10<sup>50</sup>, he famously remarked that "10<sup>50</sup> is a long way from infinity."<ref name="SUPINT" />{{Rp|217}}

Most of Shanks's number theory work was in [[computational number theory]]. He developed a number of fast computer factorization methods based on [[quadratic forms]] and the [[class number (number theory)|class number]].<ref name="Williams NAMS obit" />{{Rp|815}} His [[algorithms]] include: [[Baby-step giant-step]] algorithm for computing the [[discrete logarithm]], which is useful in [[public-key cryptography]]; [[Shanks's square forms factorization]], an [[integer factorization]] method that generalizes [[Fermat's factorization method]]; and the [[Tonelli–Shanks algorithm]] that finds square roots moduli a prime, which is useful for the [[quadratic sieve]] method of [[integer factorization]].

In 1974, Shanks and [[John Wrench]] did some of the first computer work on estimating the value of [[Brun's constant]], the sum of the reciprocals of the [[twin prime]]s, calculating it over the twin primes among the first two million primes.<ref name="Shanks & Wrench Brun's Constant">
{{cite journal
 | last = Shanks
 | first = Daniel
 |author2=[[John W. Wrench, Jr.]]
 |date=January 1974
 | title = Brun's Constant
 | journal = Mathematics of Computation
 | volume = 28
 | issue = 125
 | pages = 293–299
 | issn = 0025-5718
 | doi = 10.2307/2005836
 | jstor = 2005836
 | publisher = Mathematics of Computation, Vol. 28, No. 125
}}
</ref>

[[USSR State Prize]] }} '''Naum Zuselevich Shor''' ({{lang-ru|'''Наум Зуселевич Шор'''}}) (1 January 1937 – 26 February 2006) was a [[USSR|Soviet]] and [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] [[mathematician]] specializing in [[optimization (mathematics)|optimization]]. He made significant contributions to [[nonlinear programming|nonlinear]] and [[stochastic programming]], numerical techniques for [[subgradient method|non-smooth optimization]], [[discrete optimization]] problems, [[semidefinite programming|matrix optimization]], [[Lagrange duality|dual quadratic bounds]] in [[Multiobjective optimization|multi-extremal programming]] problems. Shor became a full member of the [[National Academy of Science of Ukraine]] in 1998. ==Subgradient methods== {{Main|Subgradient method}} {{See also|Ellipsoid method|Linear programming|Convex optimization|Computational complexity theory|Iterative method}} N. Z. Shor is well known for his [[iterative method|method]] of [[subgradient|generalized]] [[gradient descent]] with [[Quasi-Newton method|space dilation]] in the direction of the difference of two successive [[subgradient]]s (the so-called r-algorithm), that was created in collaboration with Nikolay G. Zhurbenko.N. Z. Shor and N. G. Zhurbenko, "The minimization method using space dilatation in direction of difference of two sequential gradients," Kibernetika, No. 3, 51-59 (1971). Free implementations of r-algorithm (made by workers of Department Methods for solving complex optimization problems led for a long time by N. Z. Shor) are available in * [http://imsc.uni-graz.at/kuntsevich/solvopt/ SolvOpt] * [http://openopt.org/ralg ralg] from [[OpenOpt|OpenOpt framework]]. The [[ellipsoid method]] was re-invigorated by A.S. Nemirovsky and D.B. Yudin, who developed a careful [[Analysis of algorithms|complexity analysis]] of its [[approximation algorithm|approximation]] properties for problems of [[convex minimization]] with real data. However, it was [[Leonid Khachiyan]] who provided the rational-arithmetic complexity analysis, using an [[ellipsoid method|ellipsoid]] '''[[algorithm]]''', that established that [[linear programming]] problems can be solved in polynomial time. It has long been known that the ellipsoidal methods are special cases of these subgradient-type methods. == r-algorithm == Shor's '''r-algorithm''' is for unconstrained minimization of (possibly) non-smooth functions,N.Z. Shor. ''Minimization Methods for Non-differentiable Functions''. Springer-Verlag, New York, 1985. which has been somewhat popular despite an unknown [[Rate of convergence|convergence rate]]."The Speed of Shor's R-Algorithm", available at http://www.optimization-online.org/DB_HTML/2007/05/1656.html It can be viewed as a [[Quasi-Newton method]], although it does not satisfy the secant equation. Although the method involves [[Subderivative|subgradients]], it is distinct from his so-called ''subgradient method'' described above. == References == ===Notes=== ===Bibliography=== * {{Citation | title=Congratulations to Naum Shor on his 65th birthday | doi=10.1023/A:1020215832722 | year=2002 | journal=Journal of Global Optimization | volume=24 | issue=2 | pages=111–114}}. ==External links== * [http://www.ballarat.edu.au/ard/itms/CIAO/ORBNewsletter/issue5.shtml#12 ORB Newsletter Issue 5] contains an article with a short biography {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Shor, Naum Z.}} [[Category:Numerical analysts]] [[Category:Theoretical computer scientists]] [[Category:Mathematical analysts]] [[Category:Ukrainian mathematicians]] [[Category:Soviet computer scientists]] [[Category:Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv alumni]] [[Category:Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology faculty]] [[Category:Members of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine]] [[Category:Recipients of the USSR State Prize]] [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:Ukrainian Jews]]

pages.title: Valeria Simoncini
pages.text:
'''Valeria Simoncini''' (born 1966){{r|born}} is an Italian researcher in [[numerical analysis]] who works as a professor in the mathematics department at the [[University of Bologna]].{{r|cv}} Her research involves the computational solution of equations involving large [[Matrix (mathematics)|matrices]], and their applications in scientific computing.{{r|unibo}}

==Education and career==
Simoncini earned a degree from the University of Bologna in 1989, became a visiting scholar at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign]] from 1991 to 1993, and completed her PhD at the [[University of Padua]] in 1994. After working at [[National Research Council (Italy)|CNR]] from 1995 to 2000, she returned to Bologna as an associate professor in 2000, and was promoted to full professor in 2010.{{r|cv}}

==Book==
With Antonio Navarra, she is the author of the book ''A Guide to Empirical Orthogonal Functions for Climate Data Analysis'' (Springer, 2010).

==Recognition==
In 2014 she was elected as a [[fellow]] of the [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics]] "for contributions to numerical linear algebra".{{r|sf}}

[[Oswald Veblen Prize in Geometry]] (1966)
[[Sloan Fellowship]] (1960) }} '''Stephen Smale''' (born July 15, 1930) is an American [[mathematician]], known for his research in [[topology]], [[dynamical system]]s and [[mathematical economics]]. He was awarded the [[Fields Medal]] in 1966{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/10/opinion/sunday/how-math-got-its-nobel-.html?_r=0|title=How Math Got Its ‘Nobel’|date=8 August 2014|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=21 October 2016}} and spent more than three decades on the mathematics faculty of the [[University of California, Berkeley]] (1960–1961 and 1964–1995). ==Education and career== Smale was born in [[Flint, Michigan]] and entered the [[University of Michigan]] in 1948.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HcmcAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA225|title=The Britannica Guide to Geometry|date=2010|publisher=Britannica Educational Publishing|isbn=9781615302178|editor=William L. Hosch|page=225}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C1cLnAm7gcwC&pg=PA11|title=Steven Smale: The Mathematician Who Broke the Dimension Barrier|last=Batterson|first=Steve|date=2000|publisher=American Mathematical Soc.|isbn=9780821826966|page=11}} Initially, he was a good student, placing into an honors [[calculus]] sequence taught by Bob Thrall and earning himself A's. However, his [[Sophomore year|sophomore]] and junior years were marred with mediocre grades, mostly Bs, Cs and even an F in [[nuclear physics]]. However, with some luck, Smale was accepted as a graduate student at the University of Michigan's mathematics department. Yet again, Smale performed poorly in his first years, earning a C average as a graduate student. It was only when the department chair, [[Theophil Henry Hildebrandt|Hildebrandt]], threatened to kick Smale out that he began to work hard.{{YouTube|LmpPUjOeMGI}} Smale finally earned his [[Ph.D.]] in 1957, under [[Raoul Bott]]. Smale began his career as an instructor at the college at the [[University of Chicago]]. In 1958, he astounded the mathematical world with a proof of a [[sphere eversion]]. He then cemented his reputation with a proof of the [[Poincaré conjecture]] for all dimensions greater than or equal to 5, published in 1961; in 1962 he generalized the ideas in a 107-page paper that established the [[h-cobordism theorem]]. After having made great strides in [[topology]], he then turned to the study of [[dynamical systems]], where he made significant advances as well. His first contribution is the [[Horseshoe map|Smale horseshoe]] that started significant research in dynamical systems. He also outlined a research program carried out by many others. Smale is also known for injecting [[Morse theory]] into mathematical [[economics]], as well as recent explorations of various theories of [[computation]]. In 1998 he compiled a list of 18 problems in [[mathematics]] to be solved in the 21st century, known as [[Smale's problems]]. This list was compiled in the spirit of [[David Hilbert|Hilbert]]'s famous list of problems produced in 1900. In fact, Smale's list contains some of the original Hilbert problems, including the [[Riemann hypothesis]] and the second half of [[Hilbert's sixteenth problem]], both of which are still unsolved. Other famous problems on his list include the [[Poincaré conjecture]] (now a theorem, proved by [[Grigori Perelman]]), the [[P = NP problem]], and the [[Navier–Stokes existence and smoothness|Navier–Stokes equations]], all of which have been designated [[Millennium Prize Problems]] by the [[Clay Mathematics Institute]]. Earlier in his career, Smale was involved in controversy over remarks he made regarding his work habits while proving the higher-dimensional Poincaré conjecture. He said that his best work had been done "on the beaches of Rio."He discovered the famous [[Smale horseshoe map]] on a beach in [[Leme (Rio de Janeiro)|Leme]], [[Rio de Janeiro]]. See: S. Smale (1996), [http://math.berkeley.edu/~smale/biblio/chaos.ps Chaos: Finding a Horseshoe on the Beaches of Rio]. This led to the withholding of his grant money from the [[National Science Foundation|NSF]]. He has been politically active in various movements in the past, such as the [[Free Speech movement]] and the movement against the Vietnam War. At one time he was [[subpoena]]ed by the [[House Un-American Activities Committee]]. In 1960 Smale was appointed an associate professor of mathematics at the [[University of California, Berkeley]], moving to a professorship at [[Columbia University]] the following year. In 1964 he returned to a professorship at UC Berkeley where he has spent the main part of his career. He retired from UC Berkeley in 1995 and took up a post as professor at the [[City University of Hong Kong]]. He also amassed over the years one of the finest private mineral collections in existence. Many of Smale's mineral specimens can be seen in the book—''The Smale Collection: Beauty in Natural Crystals''.{{cite web|url=http://www.lithographie.org/bookshop/the_smale_collection.htm|title=Lithographie LTD|author=|date=|website=www.lithographie.org}} Since 2002 Smale is a Professor at the [[Toyota Technological Institute at Chicago]]; starting August 1, 2009, he is also a Distinguished University Professor at the [[City University of Hong Kong]].[http://ttic.uchicago.edu/~smale/vita.html Stephen Smale Vita.] Accessed November 18, 2009. In 2007, Smale was awarded the [[Wolf Prize]] in mathematics.{{cite web|url=http://www.huji.ac.il/cgi-bin/dovrut/dovrut_search_eng_dev.pl?mesge116895485932688760|title=The Hebrew University of Jerusalem - Division of Marketing & Communication|author=|date=|website=www.huji.ac.il}} == Important publications == * {{cite news | first=Stephen | last=Smale | title=Generalized Poincaré's conjecture in dimensions greater than four | journal=[[Annals of Mathematics]] | volume=74 | year=1961 | pages=391–406 | mr=0137124 | doi=10.2307/1970239 | issue=2}} * {{cite news | first=Stephen | last=Smale | title=Differentiable dynamical systems | mr=0228014 | journal=[[Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society]] | volume=73 | year=1967 | pages=747–817 | doi=10.1090/S0002-9904-1967-11798-1}} * F. '''Maria Adelaide Sneider''' (6 December 1937 – 1 May 1989)<ref name="deathdate"/> (also known as '''Maria Adelaide Sneider Ludovici''', her second [[surname]] being "Ludovici")<ref>As she signes herself in {{harv|Sneider Ludovici|1970}} and in several other of her scientific works: see also the "Author index" in {{Harv|Fichera|1974|p=202}}.</ref> was an [[Italia]]n [[mathematician]] working on [[numerical analysis|numerical]] and [[mathematical analysis]]. She is known for her work on the [[Capacity of a set|theory of electrostatic capacities]] of non-smooth [[Closed set|closed]] [[hypersurface]]s:<ref>According to {{harvtxt|Fichera|1990|p=395}}: see also her work {{harv|Sneider Ludovici|1970}}, the associated report {{harv|Picone|Tricomi|Fichera|1970}}, and the introductory remarks in {{harv|Hayman|1993|p=119}}.</ref> Apart from the development of precise estimates for the [[numerical approximation]] of the electrostatic [[Capacitance#Capacitance of simple systems|capacity]] of the unit [[cube]],<ref>See {{harv|Picone|Tricomi|Fichera|1970}}, {{Harv|Fichera|1990|p=396}} and {{harv|Hayman|1993|p=119}}.</ref> this work also led her to give a rigorous proof of [[Green's identities]] for large classes of hypersurfaces with singularities,<ref>See {{Harv|Fichera|1974|pp=178–179}} and {{Harv|Fichera|1990|pp.=396–397}}.</ref> and later to develop an accurate mathematical analysis of the [[points effect]].<ref>See {{harvtxt|Fichera|1990|pp=398–400}}.</ref> She is also known for her contributions to the [[Dirichlet problem]] for [[pluriharmonic function]]s on the unit [[sphere]] of ℂ<sup>''n''</sup>.<ref>{{Harv|Fichera|1990|p=405}}.</ref>

pages.title: Irene Stegun
pages.text:
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Stegun.jpg|thumb|Irene Stegun {{deletable image-caption|Monday, 21 December 2009}}]] -->
'''Irene Ann Stegun''' (February 9, 1919 – January 27, 2008)<ref name=obit>{{cite web |url=http://www.nyjnews.com/obituary/obit.php3?id=2440443 |title=Obituary Stegun, Irene A. |publisher=[[The Journal News]] |date=2008-01-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727212112/http://www.nyjnews.com/obituary/obit.php3?id=2440443 |archive-date=2011-07-27}}</ref> was a [[mathematics|mathematician]] at the [[NIST|National Bureau of Standards]] who, with [[Milton Abramowitz]], edited a classic book of [[mathematical table]]s called ''A Handbook of Mathematical Functions'', widely known as ''[[Abramowitz and Stegun]]''.<ref>{{cite interview |title=The Author and Her Subject: Kathleen Broome Williams on Grace Murray Hopper ''(on: Kathleen Broome Williams (2004). ''Grace Hopper: Admiral of the Cyber Sea''. Naval Institute Press, Annapolis, Maryland, USA)'' |author-first=Philip J. |author-last=Davis |author-link=Philip J. Davis |others=Kathleen Broome Williams |date=2005-05-01 |type=Book review |publisher=[[SIAM News]] |url=http://www.siam.org/news/news.php?id=57|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170503035747/http://www.siam.org/news/news.php?id=57|archive-date=2017-05-03}}</ref> When Abramowitz died of a heart attack in 1958, Stegun took over management of the project and finished the work by 1964, working under the direction of the NBS Chief of [[Numerical Analysis]] [[Philip J. Davis]], who was also a contributor to the book.

Stegun was born in [[Yonkers, New York]].<ref name=obit/>
She began her mathematical career during the Second World War. After teaching mathematics at a Catholic school in New York, she joined the Planning Committee of the [[Mathematical Tables Project]] of the [[Works Progress Administration|WPA]].  In that role, she learned the basics of [[numerical analysis]] from the committee's chair, [[Gertrude Blanch]]. While working at the Mathematics Tables Project, she completed a master's degree in mathematics at [[Columbia University]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Grier|first=David Alan|title=Irene Stegun, The Handbook of Mathematical Functions and the Lingering Influence of the New Deal|journal=American Mathematical Monthly|date=August 2006|volume=113|issue=7|pages=585–597|doi=10.2307/27642002|jstor=27642002}}</ref>

In 1948, Stegun and a handful of other members of the Mathematical Tables Project moved to Washington, DC, where they set up the Computation Laboratory of the National Bureau of Standards, now [[NIST]]. She eventually rose to assistant chief of the Computation Laboratory at NBS. In 1965, Stegun was awarded a Gold Medal from the [[United States Department of Commerce|Department of Commerce]] for her efforts in completing the project. She held the position of assistant chief of the Computing Lab until she became the interim director in 1965.

MA 1985 |doctoral_advisor = |known_for = |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |awards = {{Plainlist| * Foreign Member of the [[Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts]] (2009) * Fellow of the [[European Academy of Sciences]] (2010) * [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|SIAM Fellow]] (2016)}} |influences = |influenced = |prizes = |religion = |footnotes = |signature = | website = {{URL|http://people.maths.ox.ac.uk/suli}} }} '''Endre Süli''' (also, Endre Suli) is Professor of [[Numerical Analysis]] in the [[The Mathematical Institute, University of Oxford|Mathematical Institute]], [[University of Oxford]], [[Fellow]] and [[Tutor]] in Mathematics at [[Worcester College, Oxford]] and [[wikt:supernumerary|Supernumerary]] Fellow of [[Linacre College, Oxford]]. He was educated at the [[University of Belgrade]] and, as a [[British Council]] Visiting Student, at the [[University of Reading]] and [[St Catherine's College, Oxford]]. His research is concerned with the mathematical analysis of numerical algorithms for nonlinear partial differential equations. ==Biography== Süli is a Foreign Member of the [[Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts]] (2009), Fellow of the [[European Academy of Sciences]] (2010), and a Fellow of the [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics]] (2016).[http://fellows.siam.org/index.php?sort=year&value=2016 "SIAM Fellows: Class of 2016"]. He was invited speaker at the [[list of International Congresses of Mathematicians Plenary and Invited Speakers|International Congress of Mathematicians]] in Madrid in 2006{{cite web|url=http://www.icm2006.org/|title=International Congress of Mathematicians, Madrid, 2006}} and was Chair of the [[Foundations of Computational Mathematics|Society for the Foundations of Computational Mathematics]] (2002–2005).{{cite web|url=http://focm-society.org/|title=Foundations of Computational Mathematics}} Other honours include: [[Fellow of the Institute of Mathematics and its Applications]] (FIMA, 2007), Charlemagne Distinguished Lecture (2011), IMA Service Award (2011), Professor Hospitus Universitatis Carolinae Pragensis, [[Charles University in Prague]] (2012–), Distinguished Visiting Chair Professor [[Shanghai Jiao Tong University]] (2013–), President, SIAM United Kingdom and Republic of Ireland Section (2013–2015), [[London Mathematical Society]]/[[New Zealand Mathematical Society]] Forder Lecturer (2015),{{cite web|url=https://www.lms.ac.uk/events/lectures/forder-and-aitken-lectureship/|title=LMS-NZMS Forder Lectureship}} Aziz Lecture (2015), BIMOS Distinguished Lecture (2016), John von Neumann Lecture (2016). {{cite web|url=http://wwwmath.uni-muenster.de/Demain/JohnvonNeumannLecture/|title=John von Neumann Lecture, University of Münster}} Since 2005 Süli has been co-Editor-in-Chief of the IMA Journal of Numerical Analysis{{cite web|url=http://imajna.oxfordjournals.org/|title=IMA Journal of Numerical Analysis}} and is a [http://global.oup.com/about/structure?cc=gb Delegate] of [[Oxford University Press]]. He is a member of the Scientific Committee of the Mathematisches Forschungsinstitut Oberwolfach ([[Mathematical Research Institute of Oberwolfach]]), the Scientific Council of [[Société de Mathématiques Appliquées et Industrielles]] (SMAI), the Scientific Advisory Board of the Berlin Mathematics Research Center MATH+,{{cite web|url=http://www.mathplus.de|title=Berlin Mathematics Research Center MATH+}} and was a member of the Scientific Steering Committee of the [[Isaac Newton Institute for Mathematical Sciences]] at the [[University of Cambridge]] (2011–2014), the Scientific Advisory Board of the [[Berlin Mathematical School]] (2016–2018), and the Scientific Advisory Board of the Archimedes Center for Modeling, Analysis and Computation at the University of Crete (2010–2014).{{cite web|url=http://www.acmac.uoc.gr/|title=Archimedes Center for Modeling, Analysis and Computation}} He is the father of Sterija Award-winning Serbian playwright Fedor Süli (also, pages.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Eitan Tadmor | image = Eitan Tadmor 2015.jpg | image_size = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1954|05|04}} | birth_place = | nationality = [[United States|American]], [[Israel]]i | doctoral_advisor = [http://history.siam.org/oralhistories/arbarbanel.htm Saul Abarbanel] | doctoral_students = | known_for = [http://www.cscamm.umd.edu/centpack/ High resolution central schemes]
[http://www2.cscamm.umd.edu/tadmor/entropy_stability/ Entropy stable schemes]
[http://www2.cscamm.umd.edu/tadmor/spectral_viscosity/ Spectral viscosity methods]
[http://www2.cscamm.umd.edu/tadmor/hierarchical_decompositions/ Hierarchical decomposition]
[http://www.cscamm.umd.edu/tadmor/pub/subject.htm#self-organized Self-organized dynamics] | field = [[Applied Mathematics]] | work_institutions = [[Tel-Aviv University]], [[UCLA]], [[University of Maryland, College Park]] | prizes = }} '''Eitan Tadmor''' (born May 4, 1954) is a distinguished university professor at the [[University of Maryland, College Park]], known for his contributions to the theory and computation of [[Partial differential equation|PDE]]s with diverse applications to [[shock wave]], [[Boltzmann equation|kinetic transport]], [[incompressible flow]]s, [[image processing]], and self-organized collective dynamics.{{citation | last1 = Bao | first1 = W. | last2 = Mishra | first2 = S. | last3 = Tao | first3 = T. | doi = 10.4208/cicp.scpde14.preface | volume = 19 | issue = 5 | journal = Communications in Computational Physics | pages = i–iii | title = Prefer: Special Issue Dedicated to Professor Eitan Tadmor’s 60th Birthday | url = http://www.cscamm.umd.edu/people/faculty/tadmor/lineage/CiCP%2019(5)%20TN60@HK%20dedication%202016.pdf | year = 2016}}. == Academic biography == Tadmor completed his mathematical studies ([[B.Sc.]], 1973, [[M.Sc.]], 1975, [[Ph.D.]], 1978) at [[Tel-Aviv University]]. In 1980-1982 he was a Bateman Research Instructor in [[California Institute of Technology|Caltech]]. He returned to his alma mater, and held professorship positions at [[Tel-Aviv University]] during 1983-1998, where he chaired the Department of Applied Mathematics (1991-1993). He moved to [[UCLA]] (1995-2002), where he was the founding co-director of the NSF [[Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics]] (IPAM) (1999-2001). In 2002 he joined the [[University of Maryland, College Park]], serving as the founding Director of the University [[Center for Scientific Computation and Mathematical Modeling]] (CSCAMM), (2002-2016). He is on the faculty of the Department of Mathematics, the Institute for Physical Sciences and Technology and CSCAMM. In 2012 he was awarded as the PI of the NSF Research network "Kinetic Description of Emerging Challenges in Natural Sciences" ([http://www.ki-net.umd.edu/ KI-Net]), (2012-2018).{{citation | last1 = Kurganov | first1 = A. | last2 = Lazarov | first2 = R. | last3 = Levy | first3 = D. | last4 = Petrova | first4 = G. | last5 = Popov | first5 = B. | doi = 10.2478/cmam-2004-0015 | issue = 3 | journal = Computational Methods in Applied Mathematics | mr = 2117474 | pages = 265–270 | title = Eitan Tadmor—50 | url = http://www.cscamm.umd.edu/tadmor/lineage/CMAM%20Vol=4%20%283%29%20Tadmor%20-%2050.pdf | volume = 4 | year = 2004}}. == Research contributions == Tadmor has made a series of fundamental contributions to the development of high-resolution methods for nonlinear conservation laws, introducing the classes of sentral schemes, entropy stable schemes and spectral viscosity methods. He was involved in work on kinetic theories and critical thresholds phenomena in nonlinear transport models. He introduced novel ideas of multi-scale hierarchical descriptions of images, and is leading an interdisciplinary program on self-collective dynamics with applications to flocking and opinion dynamics. Tadmor has been an adviser of more than 30 PhD students and postdoctoral fellows, several of whom have become leaders in their own right. == Honors == Tadmor was listed on the 2003 [[ISI Highly Cited|ISI most cited researchers in Mathematics]]. He has given numerous invited lectures, including an invited lecture at the 2002 [[International Congress of Mathematicians]] (ICM) ([[Beijing]]), plenary addresses in the international conferences on hyperbolic problems ([[Zürich]] 1990 and [[Beijing]] 1998), and the 2008 Foundations of Computational Mathematics meeting in [[Hong Kong]], and the SIAM invited address at the 2014 Joint Mathematical meeting in [[Baltimore]]. In 2012 he was in the inaugural class of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society.[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2015-01-14. In 2015 he was awarded the SIAM-ETH Henrici prize for ″original, broad and fundamental contributions to the applied and numerical analysis of nonlinear differential equations and their applications in areas such as fluid dynamics, image processing and social dynamics".[http://www.siam.org/prizes/sponsored/henrici.php Peter Henrici Prize], SIAM, retrieved 2015-01-14. He has published more than one hundred and fifty [http://www.cscamm.umd.edu/people/faculty/tadmor/pub/significant.htm research papers] in Numerical Analysis and Applied Partial Differential Equations. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.cscamm.umd.edu/people/faculty/tadmor/index.htm Tadmor's home page] at [[University of Maryland, College Park]] *{{MathGenealogy|id=36689}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tadmor, Eitan}} [[Category:20th-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:Israeli mathematicians]] [[Category:Computational fluid dynamicists]] [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Tel Aviv University alumni]] [[Category:Tel Aviv University faculty]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles faculty]] [[Category:University of Maryland, College Park faculty]] [[Category:Numerical analysts]] [[Category:ISI highly cited researchers]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Mathematical Society]]

[[Royal Society Wolfson Research Merit Award]] {{cite web|url=https://royalsociety.org/news/2014/wolfson-merit-awards-may/|title=Royal Society announces new round of esteemed Wolfson Research Merit Awards |publisher=[[Royal Society]]|access-date=April 18, 2018}}{{small|(2014)}} Olga Taussky-Todd Lecturer {{Cite web|url=http://www.iciam.org/olga-taussky-todd-lecture-iciam-2019|title=The Olga Taussky-Todd Lecture at ICIAM 2019 {{!}} ICIAM|website=www.iciam.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-10}}{{small|(2019)}} }} '''Françoise Tisseur''' is a [[Numerical analysis|numerical analyst]] and [[Professor#The United Kingdom.2C Ireland and other English speaking countries|Professor]] of Numerical Analysis{{cite web|url=http://www.manchester.ac.uk/research/francoise.tisseur|title=Françoise Tisseur – Personal Details|author=University of Manchester|accessdate=October 25, 2010}} at the [[School of Mathematics, University of Manchester]], [[UK]]. She works in [[numerical linear algebra]] and in particular on [[Nonlinear eigenproblem|nonlinear eigenvalue problem]]s and structured [[matrix (mathematics)|matrix]] problems, including the development of algorithms and software.{{cite web|url=http://www.manchester.ac.uk/research/francoise.tisseur/research|title=Françoise Tisseur – Research|author=University of Manchester|accessdate=August 26, 2012}} She is a graduate of the [[:fr:Université de Saint-Étienne|University of St-Etienne]], France, from where she gained her Maitrise (Mathematical Engineering) in 1993, Diplome d’Etude Approfondie in 1994, and PhD (Numerical Analysis) in 1997. She has contributed software to [[LAPACK]], [[ScaLAPACK]], and the [[MATLAB]] distribution. Tisseur is a member of the editorial boards of the SIAM Journal on Matrix Analysis and Applications, the IMA Journal of Numerical Analysis and the Electronic Journal of Linear Algebra. == Awards and honours == Tisseur was awarded the 2010 [[Whitehead Prize]] by the [[London Mathematical Society]] for her research achievements in numerical linear algebra, including polynomial eigenvalue and structured matrix problems. She was awarded the 2011-2012 [[Adams Prize]] of the [[University of Cambridge]] for her work on [[polynomial eigenvalue problem]]s and holds a Royal Society Wolfson Research Merit Award in 2014-2019. She will deliver the Olga Taussky-Tood Lecture at the International Congress on Industrial and Applied Mathematics in Valencia, Spain, in 2019.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iciam.org/olga-taussky-todd-lecture-iciam-2019|title=The Olga Taussky-Todd Lecture at ICIAM 2019 {{!}} ICIAM|website=www.iciam.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-10}} Tisseur [[File:John Todd.jpeg|thumb|220px|Jack Todd]]
'''John (Jack) Todd''' (May 16, 1911 – June 21, 2007) was a Northern Irish mathematician most of whose career was spent in England and the USA; he was a pioneer in the field of [[numerical analysis]].

He was born in Carnacally, [[County Down]], Ireland, and grew up near [[Belfast]]. He attended [[Methodist College Belfast]] after winning a scholarship. In his final year at the College he only studied maths as a result of his desire to become an engineer.<ref name=stat>{{cite web|last1=O'Connor|first1=JJ|last2=Robertson|first2=EF|title=John Todd|url=http://www-groups.dcs.st-and.ac.uk/~history/Biographies/Todd_John.html|website=School of Mathematics and Statistics, University of St Andrews|accessdate=31 July 2016}}</ref> He received his BSc degree from [[Queen's University Belfast|Queen's University]] in 1931, and went to [[St John's College, Cambridge|St. John's College]] at [[Cambridge University]], studying for 2 years with [[John Edensor Littlewood|J. E. Littlewood]], who advised him against getting a doctorate and just to do research.

He taught at [[Queens University Belfast]] 1933-1937, and was an invited speaker at the 1936 ICM in Oslo<ref>[[List_of_International_Congresses_of_Mathematicians_Plenary_and_Invited_Speakers#1936,_Oslo|1936 ICM in Oslo]]</ref> on "Transfinite Superpositions of Absolutely Continuous Functions"<ref>[https://www.mathunion.org/fileadmin/ICM/Proceedings/ICM1936.2/ICM1936.2.ocr.pdf Congrès International Des Mathématiciens Oslo 1936]</ref>

He worked at [[King's College London|King's College]] in London for the years 1937–1939 (and again 1945–1947), where he met [[Olga Taussky]], a matrix and number theorist (she had also been an invited speaker in Oslo). They were married in 1938. Todd returned to Belfast to teach at [[Methodist College Belfast]] 1940-1941.[1] As part of the war effort, he had worked for the British Admiralty 1941-1945. One of Todd's greatest achievements was the preservation of the [[Mathematical Research Institute of Oberwolfach]] in Germany at the end of the war.<ref>{{cite web|title=Professor John Todd|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1556507/Professor-John-Todd.html|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=31 July 2016}}</ref>

In 1945 the Todds emigrated to the United States and worked for the [[National Bureau of Standards]]. In 1957 they joined the faculty of [[California Institute of Technology]] in Pasadena, California.

Todd retired from the faculty, and in May, 2001 was honored by a symposium at Caltech in honor of his 90th birthday. He was called Jack Todd by all who knew him.  He died at his home in Pasadena, California on June 21, 2007.

Trefethen}}</ref><ref name="howfast">{{Cite journal | last1 = Nachtigal | first1 = N. L. M. | last2 = Reddy | first2 = S. C. | last3 = Trefethen | first3 = L. N. | doi = 10.1137/0613049 | title = How Fast are Nonsymmetric Matrix Iterations? | journal = SIAM Journal on Matrix Analysis and Applications | volume = 13 | issue = 3 | pages = 778 | year = 1992 | citeseerx = 10.1.1.210.62 }}</ref>

==Education==
Trefethen was born 30 August 1955 in [[Boston, Massachusetts]],<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/americanmenwomen07jaqu/page/184|title=American Men & Women of Science: Physical and Biological Sciences|last=|first=|date=1986|publisher=Bowker|others=Jaques Cattell Press.|year=1986|isbn=0835222217|edition=16th|location=New York|pages=184|oclc=13680380}}</ref> the son of mechanical engineer [[Lloyd M. Trefethen]] and codebreaker, poet, and English professor [[Florence Newman Trefethen]].<ref name="whoswho"/>

He obtained his bachelor's degree from [[Harvard University]] in 1977 and his master's from [[Stanford University]] in 1980. His PhD was on ''Wave Propagation and Stability for Finite Difference Schemes'' supervised by Joseph E. Oliger at [[Stanford University]].<ref name="mathgene"/><ref name="trephd">{{cite thesis |degree=PhD |first=Lloyd Nicholas|last=Trefethen |title=Wave Propagation and Stability for Finite Difference Schemes |publisher=Stanford University |year=1982 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/303229499|authorlink=Lloyd N. Trefethen|oclc=9136203}}</ref><ref name="acm">{{ACMPortal|id=81100259928}}</ref>

==Career and research==
Following his PhD, Trefethen went on to work at the [[Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences]] in New York, [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], and [[Cornell University]], before being appointed to a chair at the [[University of Oxford]] and a Fellowship of [[Balliol College, Oxford]].<ref name="SNC">{{cite web |url=http://www.orcca.on.ca/conferences/snc2007/site/talks/talks.html|title=SNC '07 Invited Speakers|accessdate=26 April 2008}}</ref>

{{As of|2018}}, he has published around 140 journal papers spanning a wide range of areas within numerical analysis and applied mathematics, including non-normal [[eigenvalue]] problems and applications, spectral methods for differential equations, [[numerical linear algebra]], [[fluid mechanics]], computational [[complex analysis]], and approximation theory.<ref name="pubs">{{cite web |url=http://web.comlab.ox.ac.uk/people/Nick.Trefethen/publication/publication.html |title=Nick Trefethen publication list}}</ref> He is perhaps best known for his work on [[pseudospectrum|pseudospectra]] of [[normal matrix|non-normal matrices]] and operators. This work covers theoretical aspects as well as numerical algorithms, and applications including fluid mechanics, numerical solution of partial differential equations, numerical linear algebra, shuffling of cards, random matrices, differential equations and [[lasers]]. Trefethen is currently an [[ISI highly cited researcher]].<ref name="HCR">{{cite web|url=http://highlycited.com/names/t/ |title=T – Research Analytics – Thomson Reuters |publisher=Highlycited.com |date=15 September 2011 |accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref>

Trefethen has written a number of books on numerical analysis including ''Numerical Linear Algebra''<ref>{{cite journal |author=Stewart, G. W. |title=Review: ''Numerical linear algebra'', by L. N. Trefethen and D. Bau |journal=Math. Comp. |year=1999 |volume=68 |issue=225 |pages=453–454 |url=http://www.ams.org/journals/mcom/1999-68-225/S0025-5718-99-01069-8/|doi=10.1090/S0025-5718-99-01069-8 }}</ref> with David Bau, ''Spectral Methods in MATLAB'', ''Schwarz–Christoffel Mapping''  with Tobin Driscoll, and ''Spectra and Pseudospectra: The Behavior of Nonnormal Matrices and Operators''<ref>{{cite journal|author=Higham, Nicholas J.|authorlink=Nicholas Higham|title=Review: ''Spectra and pseudospectra: the behavior of nonnormal matrices and operators'', by L. N. Trefethen and M. Embree|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc. (N.S.)|year=2007|volume=44|issue=2|pages=277–284|url=http://www.ams.org/journals/bull/2007-44-02/S0273-0979-06-01128-1/|doi=10.1090/s0273-0979-06-01128-1}}</ref> with [[Mark Embree]].<ref name="embree"/> He has recently been heavily involved in the creation and development of the [[MATLAB]]-based [[Chebfun]] software project.

In 2013 he proposed a new formula to calculate the [[body mass index|BMI]] of a person:<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://people.maths.ox.ac.uk/trefethen/bmi.html | title=New BMI (New Body Mass Index)}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-21229387 | title=Does the BMI need correcting?| work=BBC News| date=2013-01-29| last1=Stephenson| first1=Wesley}}</ref>

: <math> \text{BMI} = 1.3 \times \frac{\text{weight}\,\,\,\,}{\text{height}^{2.5}}</math>

([[International System of Units]])

===Notable publications===
* ''Numerical Linear Algebra'' (1997) with David Bau
* ''Spectral Methods in Matlab'' (2000)
* "Hydrodynamic stability without eigenvalues"<ref name="science">{{Cite journal | last1 = Trefethen | first1 = L. N. | last2 = Trefethen | first2 = A. E. | last3 = Reddy | first3 = S. C. | last4 = Driscoll | first4 = T. A. | title = Hydrodynamic Stability Without Eigenvalues | doi = 10.1126/science.261.5121.578 | journal = Science | volume = 261 | issue = 5121 | pages = 578–584 | year = 1993 | pmid =  17758167| bibcode = 1993Sci...261..578T }}</ref> with Anne Trefethen, Satish Reddy, and Tobin Driscoll
* "Pseudospectra of linear operators" ''SIAM Review'' (1997)

===Awards and honours===
Trefethen was the first winner of the [[Leslie Fox Prize for Numerical Analysis]]. He is a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]],<ref>[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society]. Retrieved 27 August 2013.</ref> and a member of the [[National Academy of Engineering]] in the United States. Trefethen was elected a [[List of Fellows of the Royal Society elected in 2005|Fellow of the Royal Society (FRS) in 2005]],<ref name="royal"/> his certificate of election reads:

{{quote|Nick Trefethen is distinguished for his many seminal contributions to Numerical Analysis and its applications in Applied Mathematics and in Engineering Science. His research spans theory, algorithms, software and physical applications, particularly involving eigenvalues, pseudospectra – a concept which he introduced – and dynamics. He has an international reputation for his work on nonnormal matrices and operators. He has also made major contributions to finite difference and spectral methods for partial differential equations, numerical linear algebra, and complex analysis. His monograph Numerical Linear Algebra (SIAM, 1997) is one of the SIAM's best selling books and has already been through five printings.<ref name="royal"/>}}

In 2010 Trefethen was awarded the [[IMA Gold Medal|Gold Medal]] of the [[Institute of Mathematics and its Applications]] in recognition of his "outstanding contributions to mathematics and its applications over a period of years".<ref>{{cite web|title=IMA Gold Medal|url=https://ima.org.uk/awards-medals/ima-gold-medal/|accessdate=16 May 2018}} Institute of Mathematics and its Applications</ref>
In 2013 Trefethen was awarded the [[Naylor Prize]] and lectureship in Applied Mathematics from the [[London Mathematical Society]].<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.lms.ac.uk/prizes/list-lms-prize-winners#Naylor|title=  List of LMS prize winners|publisher= London Mathematical Society|accessdate= 25 November 2014}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Trefethen has one son and one daughter from his first marriage to [[Anne Trefethen|Anne Elizabeth Trefethen]] (née Daman).<ref name="whoswho"/>

[[University of Michigan]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[Fermi–Pasta–Ulam–Tsingou problem]] |influences = |awards = }} '''Mary Tsingou''' (married name: '''Mary Tsingou-Menzel'''; born October 14, 1928)[http://www.ieeeghn.org/wiki/index.php/Oral-History:Mary_Tsingou_Menzel Mary Tsingou Menzel]. IEEE Global History Network: Oral Histories. Accessed Nov 2012. is an [[Americans|American]] physicist and mathematician of [[Greek people|Greek]] ancestry. She is known for being one of the first programmers on the [[MANIAC]] computer at [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]] and for work in conjunction with [[Enrico Fermi]], [[John Pasta]], and [[Stanislaw Ulam]] which became the inspiration for the fields of [[chaos theory]] and [[scientific computing]]. ==Biography== Born in [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin]], her parents moved to the US from Bulgaria and were Greek. She spent several years in Bulgaria before returning to the US to attend high school and college. Menzel attended the [[University of Wisconsin]] where she majored in mathematics and education. She is known in the computational physics community for having helped in the coding of the [[Fermi–Pasta–Ulam–Tsingou problem]] at the [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]] while working as a programmer in the [[MANIAC]] group.{{cite journal |last1=Fermi |first1=E. |last2=Pasta |first2=J. |last3=Ulam |first3=S. |year=1955 |title=Studies of Nonlinear Problems |url=http://www.osti.gov/accomplishments/documents/fullText/ACC0041.pdf |id=(Accessed Nov 2012. ). Document LA-1940}} Also appeared in ''Collected Works of Enrico Fermi'', [[University of Chicago Press]], Vol.II,978–988,1965. '''Note''': In Fermi's case, this work is postmortem, published after his death in 1954. Fermi, E. et. al (1955). _______ . Front page: "Work done by: E. Fermi J. Pasta S. Ulam M. Tsingou"; and footnote: "We wish to thank Miss Mary Tsingou .... for running the computations on the Los Alamos MANIAC machine, ..." The result was an important stepping stone for [[chaos theory]]. After Fermi's death, [[James L. Tuck]] and Tsingou-Menzel repeated the original FPU results and provided strong indication that the nonlinear FPU problem might be integrable.{{cite journal |author1=J. L. Tuck |author2=M. T. Menzel |date=1972 |title=The Superperiod of the Nonlinear Weighted String (FPU) Problem |journal=Advances in Mathematics |volume=9 |issue=3 |pages=399–407 |doi=10.1016/0001-8708(72)90024-2}} In 2008, a paper published in ''[[Physics Today]]'' called to rename the FPU problem to the FPUT problem to give her proper credit for her contribution. Subsequent papers referencing the FPUT problem reflect this change.[http://www.scholarpedia.org/article/Fermi-Pasta-Ulam_nonlinear_lattice_oscillations Fermi–Pasta–Ulam nonlinear lattice oscillations]. [[Scholarpedia]], [[Digital object identifier|doi]]:[https://dx.doi.org/10.4249/scholarpedia.5538 10.4249/scholarpedia.5538]. '''Charles Francis Van Loan''' (born 1947) is an emeritus professor of [[computer science]] and the Joseph C. Ford Professor of Engineering at [[Cornell University]],<ref name="Statement From Chair">[http://www.cs.cornell.edu/annual_report/ChairStatement.htm Cornell CS Annual Report 1998-1999].</ref> He is known for his expertise in [[numerical analysis]], especially [[matrix (mathematics)|matrix]] computations.<ref>[http://fellows.siam.org/index.php?sort=year&value=2009#Charles_Van_Loan SIAM Fellowship Acknowledgement].</ref>

In 2016, Van Loan became the Dean of Faculty at Cornell University.

==Biography==
Originally from [[Orange, New Jersey]], Van Loan attended the [[University of Michigan]], where he obtained the B.S. in applied mathematics (1969) and the M.A. (1970) and Ph.D (1973) in mathematics.<ref>[http://www.news.cornell.edu/chronicle/99/6.17.99/VanLoan.html Cornell Chronicle: ''Charles Van Loan named chair of computer science''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607055046/http://www.news.cornell.edu/chronicle/99/6.17.99/VanLoan.html |date=June 7, 2011 }}.</ref> His PhD dissertation was entitled "Generalized Singular Values with Algorithms and Applications" and his thesis adviser was [[Cleve Moler]].<ref>[http://genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/id.php?id=5337 Mathematics Genealogy Project: ''Charles Francis Van Loan''].</ref> Following a postdoctorate at the [[University of Manchester]], he joined the Department of Computer Science at [[Cornell University]] in 1975, and served as the Department Chair from 1999 to 2006.<ref>[http://www.siam.org/visiting/speakers/vanloan.php SIAM Visiting Lecturer Bio: ''Professor Charles Van Loan''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613002614/http://www.siam.org/visiting/speakers/vanloan.php |date=June 13, 2010 }}.</ref>

Van Loan ran the Computer Science Graduate Program from 1982-1987 at Cornell and was the Director of the Undergraduate Studies from 1994–1998 and 1999-2003.<ref>http://www.cs.cornell.edu/cv/biographical.htm</ref> He was awarded the Ford chair in 1998.<ref name="Statement From Chair"/>  He held the position of chairman from July 1999 to June 2006.

In the spring of 2016, Van Loan retired from the Computer Science Department and was promoted to Dean of Faculty, replacing Joseph Burns.  Van Loan is the first emeritus professor to hold the position of Dean of Faculty.<ref>http://cornellsun.com/2016/03/25/faculty-elect-new-dean-of-faculty-and-associate-dean-of-faculty/</ref>

==Honors and awards==
Van Loan won the Robert Paul Advising Award in 1998, and the James and Martha D. McCormick Advising Award in 2003.<ref>[http://www.cs.cornell.edu/Information/Awards/ByEducation/index.htm Awards given to Cornell CS faculty members and researchers].</ref>  Other awards Van Loan won include the Merrill Scholar Faculty Impact Award in 1998 and 2009 and the James and Mary Tien Teaching Award, College of Engineering in 2009.<ref>http://www.cs.cornell.edu/cv/Vita.htm</ref>

In 2018 he was awarded the [[John von Neumann Lecture]] prize by the [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.siam.org/Prizes-Recognition/Major-Prizes-Lectures/Detail/john-von-neumann-lecture|title=John von Neumann Lecture|publisher= Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|accessdate= 7 September 2018}}</ref>

==Books==
Van Loan's best known book is ''Matrix Computations, 3/e'' (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1996, {{ISBN|978-0-8018-5414-9}}), written with [[Gene H. Golub]]. He is also the author of ''Handbook for Matrix Computations'' ([[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|SIAM]], 1988, {{ISBN|0-89871-227-0}}), ''Computational Frameworks for the Fast Fourier Transform'' ([[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|SIAM]], 1992, {{ISBN|0-89871-285-8}}), ''Introduction to Computational Science and Mathematics'' (Jones and Bartlett, 1996, {{ISBN|0-86720-473-7}}), and ''Introduction to Scientific Computation: A Matrix-Vector Approach Using MATLAB'' (2nd ed., Prentice-Hall, 1999, {{ISBN|0-13-949157-0}}).  His latest book is ''Insight Through Computing: A MATLAB Introduction to Computational Science and Engineering''  ([[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|SIAM]], 2009, {{ISBN|978-0-89871-691-7}}) written with K-Y Daisy Fan.<ref>https://www.amazon.com/dp/0898716918</ref>

pages.text:
{{for|the Slovak triathlete|Richard Varga (triathlete)}} {{Infobox scientist | image =Richard Varga.jpg | caption = | birth_name = Richard Steven Varga | birth_date= {{birth date and age|1928|10|9}} | birth_place = [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], [[United States|USA]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Parma, Ohio]] | nationality =[[United States|American]] | field =[[Applied Mathematics]] | work_institution =[[Bettis Atomic Power Laboratory]]
[[Case Western Reserve University]]
[[Kent State University]] | alma_mater = [[Case Institute of Technology]]
[[Harvard University]] | doctoral_advisor =[[Joseph Leonard Walsh|Joseph L. Walsh]] | influences=[[Garrett Birkhoff]] | doctoral_students = [[Philippe G. Ciarlet]] | known_for = [[Numerical analysis]]
[[Experimental mathematics]]
[[Complex analysis]]
[[1/9th Conjecture]]
[[Padé approximation]]
[[Matrix (mathematics)|Matrix theory]] | prizes = | religion = | footnotes =}} '''Richard Steven Varga''' (born October 9, 1928)[https://www.google.com/#sclient=psy&hl=en&safe=off&tbm=bks&source=hp&q=VARGA%2C+Richard+S.+Professor%3B+b%3A+Cleveland%2C+O.%2C+Oct.+9%2C+1928&aq=&aqi=&aql=&oq=&pbx=1&bav=on.2,or.r_gc.r_pw.&fp=122de9aaf3718895 Outstanding Young Men of American] is an [[United States|American]] mathematician who specializes in [[numerical analysis]] and [[linear algebra]]. He is currently an Emeritus University Professor of Mathematical Sciences at [[Kent State University]] and an adjunct Professor at [[Case Western Reserve University]]. Varga is known for his contributions to many areas of mathematics, including [[Matrix (mathematics)|matrix analysis]], [[complex analysis]], [[approximation theory]], and [[Computational science|scientific computation]]. He is the author of the classic textbook ''Matrix Iterative Analysis''.{{cite web|url=http://openlibrary.org/b/OL48526M/Matrix_iterative_analysis|title=Matrix Iterative Analysis|accessdate=19 December 2009}} Varga has been the Editor-in-Chief of the journal ''[[Electronic Transactions on Numerical Analysis]]'' (ETNA).{{cite web|url=http://etna.mcs.kent.edu/|title=Electronic Transactions on Numerical Analysis (ETNA)|accessdate=19 December 2009}} ==Birth and education== Richard Varga was born in [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]] of [[Hungarian people|Hungarian]]-born parents in 1928. He obtained a bachelor's degree in mathematics from Case Institute of Technology (present [[Case Western Reserve University]]) in 1950. Varga was a member of the [[collegiate wrestling]] team of Case. Following the advice of Professor Max Morris at Case, Varga joined [[Harvard University]] for the master's degree and obtained an A.M. in mathematics. Continuing his doctoral work at Harvard under the supervision of [[Joseph Leonard Walsh|Joseph L. Walsh]], Varga worked on the theory of [[Padé approximation|rational approximation]] of [[complex analysis|complex]] [[analytic function]]s. Varga received his Ph.D. degree in 1954 with a dissertation ''Properties of a Special Set of [[entire function|Entire Functions]] and their Respective [[partial sum|Partial Sums]]''.{{cite journal|last=Benzi|first=Michele|author2=Ljiljana Cvetković |author3=Michael Neumann |year=2006|title=Preface|journal=Numerical Algorithms|publisher=Spriger|volume=42|pages=205–206|issn=1572-9265 |url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/nt15g3h612663025/|accessdate=20 December 2009|doi=10.1007/s11075-006-9050-6}} While at Harvard, Varga also studied with [[Garrett Birkhoff]], who later came to collaborate with Varga in research both on [[iterative method]]s for differential equations and on [[positive matrix|positive matrices]] (and [[positive operator]]s on [[ordered vector space|partially ordered vector space]]s). ==Career== From 1954 until 1960, Varga worked for [[Bettis Atomic Power Laboratory]] in Pittsburgh. In 1960 he returned to [[Case Institute of Technology]] as a Professor of mathematics and remained there for the next nine years. He then moved to Kent State University as University Professor of mathematics. At Kent Varga has held numerous academic positions, including Director (1980–1988) and Research Director (1988–2006) of the Institute for Computational Mathematics. {{cite web|url=http://www.math.kent.edu/~varga/vita.html|title=Vita: Richard S. Varga|accessdate=19 December 2009}} His work includes numerical analysis—particularly iterative methods in numerical linear algebra, matrix theory, and differential equations—complex approximation theory, particularly [[Padé approximation]] (often with [[Edward B. Saff, Jr.]])—and analytic number theory, including high-precision calculations related to the [[Riemann hypothesis]]. He is also known for advocating experimentation in mathematics, and for writing a monograph surveying his contributions on scientific computing to resolve open problems and conjectures. ''Scientific Computation on Mathematical Problems and Conjectures'', CBMS-NSF Regional Conference Series in Applied Math., #60, Soc. for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, Philadelphia, 1990, 122 pp. ''MR'' 92b:65012. ''SIAM Reviews'' 35(1993), 318-320. ''Zbl''. 703.65004. ==Awards and honors== In 2012 he became a fellow of the [[American Mathematical Society]].[http://www.ams.org/profession/fellows-list List of Fellows of the American Mathematical Society], retrieved 2013-08-28. ==See also== *[[Matrix splitting]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.math.kent.edu/~varga/}} *{{MathGenealogy|id= 2675}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Varga, Richard S.}} [[Category:Numerical analysts]] [[Category:Approximation theorists]] [[Category:Mathematical analysts]] [[Category:Number theorists]] [[Category:20th-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:Kent State University faculty]] [[Category:Case Western Reserve University faculty]] [[Category:Case Western Reserve University alumni]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:People from Cleveland]] [[Category:American male sport wrestlers]] [[Category:1928 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Mathematical Society]] [[Category:Fellows of the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics]]

'''Hendrik "Henk" Albertus van der Vorst''' (born 5 May 1944, [[Venlo]])<ref>[https://profs.library.uu.nl/index.php/profrec/getprofdata/2252/142/166/0  Prof.dr. H.A. van der Vorst] at the ''Catalogus Professorum Academiæ Rheno-Traiectinæ''</ref> is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[mathematician]] and [[Emeritus Professor]] of [[Numerical Analysis]] at [[Utrecht University]].  According to the [[Institute for Scientific Information]] (ISI), his paper<ref name="bicgstab">
{{Citation
  | doi = 10.1137/0913035
  | author = H.A. van der Vorst
  | year = 1992
  | title = Bi-CGSTAB: A fast and smoothly converging variant of Bi-CG for the solution of nonsymmetric linear systems
  | journal = SIAM J. Sci. Stat. Comput.
  | volume = 13
  | pages = 631–644
| issue=2
}}
</ref> 
on the [[Biconjugate gradient stabilized method|BiCGSTAB]] method was the [[ISI highly cited researcher|most cited]] paper in the field of mathematics in the 1990s.<ref>
{{Citation
  | year = 2001
  | title = in-cites, September 2001 
  | url= http://www.in-cites.com/papers/dr-henk-van-der-vorst.html
}}
</ref>
He is a member of the [[Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences]] (KNAW) since 2002<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.knaw.nl/nl/leden/leden/5305 |title=Henk van der Vorst |language=Dutch |publisher=Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences |date= |accessdate=14 July 2015}}</ref>
and the [http://www.acti-nl.org/ Netherlands Academy of Technology and Innovation].<ref>
{{Citation
 |title=Members of the Netherlands Academy of Technology and Innovation 
 |url=http://www.acti-nl.org/smartsite.dws?ch=ACT&id=5452&lang=ENG 
 |deadurl=yes 
 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724223354/http://www.acti-nl.org/smartsite.dws?ch=ACT&id=5452&lang=ENG 
 |archivedate=2011-07-24 
 |df= 
}}
</ref>
In 2006 he was awarded a knighthood of the [[Order of the Netherlands Lion]].<ref>{{Citation
  | url = http://www.siam.org/news/news.php?id=1053
  | title = Reflections on Sir Henk van der Vorst
  |author1=Jan Brandts |author2=Bernd Fischer |author3=Andy Wathen | journal = SIAM News
  | volume = 39
  |date=December 2006
  | issue = 10
}}</ref>
Henk van der Vorst is a Fellow of [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics]] (SIAM).<ref>
{{cite web|url=http://fellows.siam.org/index.php?sort=year&value=2009|title=SIAM Fellows: Class of 2009|publisher=[[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|SIAM]]|accessdate=2009-12-18}}</ref>

His major contributions include [[Preconditioner|preconditioned]] iterative methods, in particular the ICCG (incomplete
Cholesky conjugate gradient) method (developed together with Koos Meijerink), a version of [[preconditioned conjugate gradient method]],<ref>
{{Citation
  | title = An Iterative Solution Method for Linear Systems of Which the Coefficient Matrix is a Symmetric M-Matrix
  | year = 1977
  |author1=J.A. Meijerink |author2=H.A.van der Vorst | journal = Math. Comp.
  | volume = 31
  | pages = 148–162
  | doi = 10.2307/2005786
  | jstor = 2005786
  | issue = 137
  }}</ref><ref>
{{Citation
  | author = H.A. van der Vorst
  | title = Iterative solution methods for certain sparse linear systems with a non-symmetric matrix arising from PDE-problems
  | journal = J. Comput. Phys.
  | volume =  44 
  | year = 1981
  | pages = 1–19
  | doi = 10.1016/0021-9991(81)90034-6
}}
</ref>
the [[Biconjugate gradient stabilized method|BiCGSTAB]]<ref name="bicgstab"/> and (together with Kees Vuik) GMRESR<ref>
{{Citation
  |author1=H.A. van der Vorst |author2=C. Vuik | title = GMRESR: A family of nested GMRES methods
  | journal = Numer. Lin. Alg. Appl.
  | volume = 1 
  | year = 1994
  | issue = 4
  | pages =  369–386
  | doi = 10.1002/nla.1680010404
|citeseerx=10.1.1.465.4477 }}</ref>
[[Krylov subspace]] methods and (together with Gerard Sleijpen) the Jacobi-Davidson method<ref>
{{Citation
  |author1=G.L.G. Sleijpen |author2=H.A. van der Vorst | title = A Jacobi-Davidson iteration method for linear eigenvalue problems
  | journal = SIAM J. Matrix Anal. Appl.
  | volume = 17
  | issue = 2
  | pages = 401–425
  | year = 1996
  | doi = 10.1137/S0895479894270427
| citeseerx = 10.1.1.50.2569}}
</ref>
for solving ordinary, generalized, and [[nonlinear eigenproblem|nonlinear]] [[Eigenvalue, eigenvector and eigenspace|eigenproblems]].
He has analyzed convergence behavior of the [[Conjugate gradient method|conjugate gradient]]<ref>
{{Citation
  |author1=A. van der Sluis |author2=H.A. van der Vorst | title =  The rate of convergence of conjugate gradients
  | journal = [[Numerische Mathematik]]
  | volume = 48
  | year = 1986
  | issue = 5
  | pages = 543–560
  | doi = 10.1007/BF01389450
}}
</ref> and [[Lanczos algorithm|Lanczos]] methods.  He has also developed a number of [[preconditioner]]s for parallel computers,<ref>
{{Citation
  | author = H.A. van der Vorst
  | title = High performance preconditioning
  | journal = SIAM J. Sci. Statist. Comput.
  | volume = 10 
  | year = 1989
  | issue = 6
  | pages = 1174–1185
  | doi = 10.1137/0910071
}}
</ref> including truncated [[Neumann series]] preconditioner, incomplete twisted factorizations, and the incomplete factorization based on the so-called "vdv" ordering.

He is the author of the book<ref>
{{Citation
  | author = H.A. van der Vorst
  | title = Iterative Krylov Methods for Large Linear systems
  | publisher = Cambridge University Press, Cambridge
  |date=April 2003
  | isbn = 978-0-521-81828-5
}}
</ref> 
and one of the authors of the Templates projects for linear problems<ref>

[[Lax–Wendroff method]] | prizes = | religion = | footnotes =}} '''Burton Wendroff''' (born 10 March 1930) is an [[United States|American]] applied mathematician known for his contributions to the development of numerical methods for the solution of [[hyperbolic partial differential equation]]s. The [[Lax–Wendroff method]] for the solution of hyperbolic PDE is named for Wendroff (as well as for [[Peter Lax]]). Wendroff is an Adjunct Professor at the Department of Mathematics and Statistics, [[University of New Mexico]]. He is also a retired Fellow and Associate at the [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]]. Burton Wendroff a primary author of the Chess program Lachex. Together with co-author Tony Warnock, Lachex competed at two [[World Computer Chess Championships]] at Cologne (1986) and Madrid (1992).{{cite web|url=http://www.grappa.univ-lille3.fr/icga/program.php?id=227|title=Lachex|publisher=univ-lille3.fr|accessdate=20 March 2010}}{{cite journal|last=Wendroff|first=Burton|author2=Tony Warnock |author3=Lewis Stiller |author4=Dean Mayer |author5=Ralph Brickner |date=May 1993|title=Bits and pieces: constructing chess endgame databases on parallel and vector architectures|journal=Applied Numerical Mathematics|volume=12|issue=1–3|pages=285–295|doi=10.1016/0168-9274(93)90123-9|url=https://zenodo.org/record/1258409}} ==Career and research== Wendroff received his B.A. degree in mathematics and physics from the [[New York University]] in 1951 and M.S. degree in mathematics from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] in 1952. After his M.S., Burt joined [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]] as a Staff Member. While at Los Alamos, he went to New York University to do his Ph.D. and received the degree under the supervision of [[Peter Lax]] in 1958.{{cite web|url=http://history.siam.org/pdfs2/Lax_final.pdf|title=An interview with Peter D. Lax|publisher=[[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|SIAM]]|accessdate=21 March 2010}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The title of his Ph.D. thesis was "Finite Difference Approximations to the Solutions of Partial Differential Equations". During 1966 to 1973, he served as a professor at the [[University of Denver]].{{cite web|url=http://www.math.unm.edu/~bbw/vita.08.ps|title=Resume: Burton Wendroff|accessdate=21 March 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619015208/http://math.unm.edu/~bbw/vita.08.ps|archivedate=19 June 2010|df=}} His primary area of research involves the development of [[Numerical method|numerical schemes]] for [[hyperbolic partial differential equation]]s using [[finite difference method]]. Together with Peter Lax, he has developed the now classical [[Lax–Wendroff method]].{{cite book|last=LeVeque|first=Randall J.|authorlink=Randall J. LeVeque|title=Finite volume methods for hyperbolic problems|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|year=2002|url=https://books.google.com/?id=RbydDezW_KgC&pg=PA146&dq=classical+lax-wendroff+method#v=onepage&q=classical%20lax-wendroff%20method&f=false|isbn=9780521009249}}{{cite book|last=Gustafson|first=Karl E.|title=Introduction to partial differential equations and Hilbert space methods|publisher=[[Dover Publications]]|year=1999|edition=3|url=https://books.google.com/?id=uu059Rj4x8oC&pg=RA1-PA416&dq=classical+lax-wendroff+method#v=onepage&q=classical%20lax-wendroff%20method&f=false|isbn=9780486612713}} He has developed two-dimensional HLLE [[Riemann solver]] and associated [[Godunov's scheme|Godunov-type difference scheme]] for [[gas dynamics]] problems. Wendroff has also made contribution to the early development of convergence study of [[finite element method]].{{cite web|last=Oden|first=J. Tinsley|authorlink=J. Tinsley Oden|url=http://history.siam.org/pdf/jtoden.pdf|title=Historical Comments on Finite Elements|publisher=SIAM|accessdate=21 March 2010}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Awards and honors== Wendroff was elected as SIAM Fellow of [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics]] for his "contributions to the numerical solution of [[partial differential equation]]s".{{cite web|url=http://fellows.siam.org/index.php?sort=year&value=2009|title=SIAM Fellows: Class of 2009|publisher=[[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|SIAM]]|accessdate=2010-03-21}} ==Selected publications== ;Books *Theoretical Numerical Analysis, [[Academic Press]], 1966.[http://scitation.aip.org/getabs/servlet/GetabsServlet?prog=normal&id=SIREAD000009000004000758000001&idtype=cvips&gifs=yes&ref=no Theoretical Numerical Analysis] *The Theory and Practice of Computation, Addison-Wesley, 1966. ;Articles *{{cite journal|last=Lax|first=Peter|author2=Wendroff, Burton |year=1960|title=Systems of Conservation Laws|journal=Comm. Pure Appl. Math.|publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]]|volume=13|issue=2|pages=217–237|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/r60v6360x9882245/|doi=10.1002/cpa.3160130205}} *{{cite journal|last=Lax|first=Peter D.|author2=Wendroff, Burton |year=1964|title=Difference Schemes for Hyperbolic Equations with High Order of Accuracy|journal=Comm. Pure Appl. Comput.|publisher=[[American Mathematical Society]]|volume=23|issue=105|pages=37–49|jstor=2005052|doi=10.1090/s0025-5718-1969-0239768-7}} *{{cite journal|last=Thomee|first=Vidar|author2=Wendroff, Burton |year=1974|title=Convergence estimates for Galerkin methods for variable coefficient initial value problems|journal=[[SIAM Journal on Numerical Analysis]]|publisher=[[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|SIAM]]|volume=11|issue=5|pages=1059–1068|jstor=2156042|doi=10.1137/0711081}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{MathGenealogy|id=33707}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wendroff, Burton}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:20th-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:New York University alumni]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:University of Denver faculty]] [[Category:Numerical analysts]] [[Category:Computational fluid dynamicists]] [[Category:Fellows of the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics]] [[Category:Los Alamos National Laboratory personnel]]

'''James Hardy Wilkinson''' [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]]<ref name="frs"/> (27 September 1919 – 5 October 1986) was a prominent figure in the field of [[numerical analysis]], a field at the boundary of [[applied mathematics]] and [[computer science]] particularly useful to [[physics]] and engineering.<ref>{{MacTutor Biography|id=Wilkinson}}</ref><ref name="acm">{{ACMPortal|id=81341498480}}</ref><ref name="dblp">{{DBLP|name=James Hardy Wilkinson}}</ref>

==Education==
Born in [[Strood]], England, he attended the [[Sir Joseph Williamson's Mathematical School]] in [[Rochester, Kent|Rochester]]. He studied the [[Cambridge Mathematical Tripos]] at [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], where he graduated as [[Senior Wrangler (University of Cambridge)|Senior Wrangler]].<ref>"Easily at the top of the First Class", from the MacTutor biography.</ref>

==Career==
Taking up war work in 1940, he began working on ballistics but transferred to the [[National Physical Laboratory, UK|National Physical Laboratory]]<ref name="NPL"/> in 1946, where he worked with [[Alan Turing]] on the [[Pilot ACE|ACE]]<ref>{{cite book |first=James H. |last=Wilkinson |chapter=Turing's Work at the National Physical Laboratory and the Construction of Pilot ACE, DEUCE and ACE |chapterurl= |editor1-first=Nicholas |editor1-last=Metropolis |editor2-first=J. |editor2-last=Howlett |editor3-first=Gian-Carlo |editor3-last=Rota |title=A History of Computing in the Twentieth Century |publisher=[[Academic Press]] |year=1980 |isbn=0124916503 }}</ref> computer project. Later, Wilkinson's interests took him into the numerical analysis field, where he discovered many significant [[algorithm]]s.

==Awards and honours==
Wilkinson received the [[Turing Award]] in 1970 "for his research in numerical analysis to facilitate the use of the high-speed digital computer, having received special recognition for his work in computations in linear algebra and 'backward' [[error analysis (mathematics)|error analysis]]."  In the same year, he also gave the [[Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics|Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM)]] [[John von Neumann]] Lecture.

Wilkinson also received an [[Honorary degree|Honorary Doctorate]] from [[Heriot-Watt University]] in 1973.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www1.hw.ac.uk/graduation/honorary-graduates.htm|title=Heriot-Watt University Edinburgh: Honorary Graduates|last=webperson@hw.ac.uk|website=www1.hw.ac.uk|access-date=2016-04-07}}</ref>

He was elected as a Distinguished Fellow of the [[British Computer Society]] in 1974 for his pioneering work in computer science.

The [[J. H. Wilkinson Prize for Numerical Software]] is named in his honour in 1991.

==Personal life==
Wilkinson married Heather Ware in 1945. He died at home of a heart attack on October 5, 1986. His wife and their son survived him, a daughter having predeceased him.
